get on.translation[0].definitions[0].def: if people get on, they like each other and have a friendly relationship with each other
get on.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: The two boys get on well most of the time.
I’ve always got on well with Henry.
get on.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to deal with a job or situation or to make progress
get on.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: How is George getting on at school?
How are you getting on with your essay?
I don’t know how we’ll get on without Michael.
get on.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: Be quiet and get on with your work!
get on.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to be successful in your job
get on.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: You’ll have to work hard if you want to get on.
get on.translation[0].definitions[4].def: to put a piece of clothing on
get on.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: I can’t get my boots on!
get on.translation[0].definitions[5].def: if time is getting on, it is quite late
get on.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: Come on, it’s getting on and we ought to go home.
I realized that time was getting on and we would have to hurry.
get on.translation[0].definitions[6].def: if someone is getting on, they are quite old
get on.translation[0].definitions[7].def: almost a particular age, time, number etc
get on.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: Mrs McIntyre must be getting on for 90 by now.
The total cost was getting on for $100,000.
get on.translation[0].definitions[9].exa: Will you lot stop messing around and get on with it!
get on.translation[0].definitions[10].de: to let someone do something on their own, and not help them or tell them what to do
get on.translation[0].definitions[10].ex: She wanted to decorate her room, so I just let her get on with it.
